Alignments of S. cerevisiae Zap1 with orthologs from other fungi reveal that both the regulatory zinc finger pair (ZF1/2) and the zinc finger pair located within the DNA-binding domain (ZF3/4) are conserved (Fig. 1). Residues that coordinate Zn(II) and contribute to the hydrophobic interface in the Gli zinc finger pair are highly conserved in ZF1/2 and ZF3/4. With those exceptions very little sequence conservation exists among the ZF1/2 zinc pairs domains. To test whether alternative ZF1/2 pairs from other fungi are regulated by the cellular zinc status, sequences corresponding to the S. cerevisiae AD2 from A. gossypii and C. albicans were fused to the Gal4 DNA-binding domain (GBD) and tested for zinc-regulated transactivation activity in S. cerevisiae by monitoring expression of a GAL1-lacZ reporter gene. Zinc inhibition of lacZ expression was evident with the A. gossypii and C. albicans AD2 orthologs (Fig. 2). Transactivation activity of AD2 resides predominantly in ZF2 (Fig. 3A, constructs 5 and 6). Mutations that disrupt Zn(II) binding to ZF1 and/or ZF2 render AD2 constitutively active in lacZ expression (Fig. 3A, constructs 3 and 4). To map the determinant conferring zinc regulation, we constructed a series of chimeric zinc finger pair domains in which finger motifs of the ZF3/4 pair were swapped in the ZF1/2 finger pair yielding ZF3/2 and ZF1/4 chimeric finger pair domains. These chimeras were tested with in vivo and in vitro assays. AD activity was assessed in vivo using fusions to the Gal4 DNA-binding domain. Expression of a GAL1-lacZ reporter in zinc-limited and replete cells was used to monitor transactivation activity of these fusions. Because AD2 activity maps to ZF2, the ZF1/4 chimera could not be assessed for in vivo AD activity (Fig. 3A, construct 9). The ZF3/2 chimera fused to the Gal4 DBD yielded high lacZ expression in zinc-deficient medium (Fig. 3A, construct 8). Transformants tested in zinc-replete medium showed attenuation of lacZ expression consistent with zinc regulation of AD activity within the ZF3/2 chimeric pair (Fig. 3A, construct 8). A more detailed comparison of the ZF3/2 and ZF1/2 GBD fusions over a range of zinc levels revealed that the activity of the ZF1/2 finger pair was more attenuated at higher cellular zinc levels (Fig. 3B). Thus, the chimeric ZF3/2 construct was not fully inhibited in zinc-replete cells. Immunoblot analysis of cells expressing the various zinc finger pair constructs revealed a surprising effect on protein accumulation of AD2 constructs that exhibited high transactivation activity in zinc-deficient cells (Fig. 3C). Gal4 fusions with ZF1/2 showed lower protein levels under conditions of maximal AD activity. Two constitutively active ZF1/2 constructs with Zn(II)-binding mutations were difficult to observe by immunoblot analysis. Zinc-deficient attenuation in protein levels was also observed in GBD fusions with either ZF2 or ZF1 and also with the inactive ZF3/4 finger pair. The observed diminution in protein levels in zinc-deficient cells arose from protein instability, because transcript levels of the fusion genes were not affected to any major extent by the cellular zinc status (Fig. 3C). Similar trends in protein instability were observed when the fusions were placed under the control of the ADH1 promoter and terminator regions (data not shown). The observed regulation of the ZF3/2 chimera suggested that key elements of zinc regulation reside in ZF2. In an attempt to map this determinant more precisely, we constructed two additional chimeras in which the β-hairpin and α-helix segments of ZF2 were replaced by corresponding segments from ZF4 creating chimera ZF1/ZFβ2α4(construct 10) and ZF1/ZFβ4α2(construct 11) shown schematically in Fig. 3A. GBD fusions with these chimeras were tested in vivo for GAL1-lacZ expression. Weak transactivation activity was observed in the ZF1/ZFβ4α2 chimera, and zinc regulation was observed (Fig. 3A). In contrast, no transactivation activity was observed in the ZF1/ZFβ2α4 chimera. Because no chimeric protein was detected in cell lysates (Fig. 3C), it is unclear whether the lack of GAL1-lacZ expression is due to insufficient protein or lack of transactivation domain function. The chimeric finger pairs tested in vivo were purified from Escherichia coli expressing the recombinant genes. The peptides were purified by Ni-NTA chromatography followed by cleavage and removal of the His6 purification tag (Fig. 4A). The purified ZF1/4 and ZF3/2 finger pair chimeric peptides were found to have two Zn(II) ions bound after removal of the purification tag. The zinc-peptide complexes were incubated with one of three metal ion chelators to assess relative binding avidities. Incubations with the chromogenic chelator, PAR (Zn(II) stability constant = 1017.1 m) were performed (Fig. 4B). We showed previously that Zn(II) binding to ZF3/4, but not to ZF1/2, was stable in the presence of PAR. ZF1/2-associated Zn(II) was largely depleted within a 1-h incubation with PAR, whereas ZF3/4-associated Zn(II) was predominantly retained. Replacement of the ZF2 motif with ZF4 yielding a ZF1/4 chimera pair resembled ZF3/4 in stability of Zn(II) binding (Fig. 4B). The ZF3/2 chimera pair, which exhibited limited zinc regulation in vivo, showed an intermediate response in PAR reactivity. The finger pair molecules were subjected to extended dialysis in buffer in the presence or absence of the Zn(II) chelator, 1,10-phenanthroline (1/10-OP) (stability constants = 1012.2 and 1017.1 m for the Zn(phen)2 and Zn(phen)3 complexes, respectively) (National Insitute of Standards and Technology Data base 46; critical stability constants) or EDTA (stability constant = 1016.2 for 1:1 complex). The amount of zinc retained by these peptides after overnight dialysis was determined (Fig. 4, C and D). Zn(II) was retained by each peptide sample upon dialysis in buffer, but the addition 1 mm EDTA resulted in the diminution in bound Zn(II) for the ZF1/2 and ZF3/2 pairs, whereas ZF3/4 and ZF1/4 retained their bound Zn(II). Dialysis in the presence of 1/10-OP resulted in significant zinc depletion in all constructs, but depletion in the ZF1/2 and ZF3/2 finger pairs was more pronounced. The ZF1/ZFβ2α4 and ZF1/ZFβ4α2 chimera finger pair domains were likewise purified from E. coli (Fig. 5A). Only ZF1/ZFβ2α4 was purified with 2 molar eq of bound Zn(II). The ZF1/ZFβ4α2 finger pair was isolated with only 0.5 molar eq Zinc and was not studied further. Dialysis of the Zn-ZF1/ZFβ2α4 peptide complex with 1/10-OP and EDTA revealed a surprising resistance to Zn(II) depletion similar to the ZF3/4 finger pair and the Gli finger pair domain (Fig. 5, B and C). Thus, the inclusion of the ZF4 α-helix abolished the kinetic lability of the ZF1/2 finger pair domain. A reciprocal construct was made in which the α-helix of ZF2 was inserted in the ZF3/4 finger pair domain, creating ZF3/ZFβ4α2. The inclusion of the α-helix of ZF2 destabilized Zn(II) binding in competition experiments with both 1/10-OP and EDTA (Fig. 5, B and C). The ZF1/ZFβ2α4 and ZF1/ZFβ4α2 chimeras were tested in vivo in the context of a minimal Zap1 consisting of the AD2 fused to the DBD (Fig. 6). zap1Δ cells transformed with either a VP16-Zap1 DBD fusion (construct 2) or the minimal AD2 ZAP1 (construct 3) were able to propagate in severely Zn-deficient medium. In contrast, zap1Δ cells harboring ZF1/ZFβ2α4 and ZF1/ZFβ4α2 Zap1 variants grew less well under severe zinc deficiency. This is suggestive that these variants were only partially active. Both mutant variants accumulated in zap1Δ cells to a greater extent than the active wild-type minimal Zap1 (Fig. 6B). Although both mutant variants partially complemented the zap1Δ strain, neither was sufficiently active to induce expression of a ZRE-lacZ or GAL1/lacZ reporter fusion even using the highly sensitive 4-methylumbelliferyl β-d-galactopyranoside substrate (data not shown). We cannot be certain whether the low AD activity arises from more stable Zn(II) binding or compromised AD activity in the chimera. Low AD activity appears to be the case with the ZF1/ZFβ4α2 variant in Fig. 3. The ZF1/2 finger pair domain has a longer linker compared with ZF3/4 or the Gli finger pair domain (Fig. 1). To assess whether the linker contributed to Zn(II) binding lability, we engineered a ZF1/2 pair linked by the ZF3/4 linker peptide (ZF1/2(3/4 link)). Dialysis of linker variant ZF1/2 finger pair with 1/10-OP and EDTA revealed a Zn(II) exchange profile similar to that of the wild-type ZF1/2 domain (Fig. 5, B and C). The effect of mutations in one finger was assessed in both ZF1/2 and ZF3/4 finger pair peptides. Double mutations in which the two histidyl ligands in ZF2 and ZF4 were substituted with glutamines (i.e. C2H2 → C2Q2) were engineered. The resulting mutant finger pairs contained only one wild-type site. Mutant genes were expressed in E. coli, and the proteins were purified (Fig. 4A). Whereas each mutant construct contained a single Zn(II) ion after Ni-NTA chromatography, the subsequent gel filtration step resulted in depletion of the bound Zn(II) ions. Thus, stable Zn(II) binding requires metallation of both sites in a finger pair domain. To corroborate these results, the Zn(II) ions in the ZF3/4 finger pair peptide were replaced with 113Cd(II) ions, and the resulting Cd2-peptide complex was evaluated by 113Cd NMR spectroscopy. Two resonances at 580 and 589 ppm were observed (Fig. 7A). The observed chemical shifts are consistent with the known S2N2 coordination of zinc finger motifs. Integration of the two signals revealed a 1:1 population of the two similar Cd(II) sites. The ZF3/4 finger pair peptide was next reconstituted with a single Cd(II), and the Cd1-ZF3/4 peptide was subjected to NMR analysis. The sample as purified contained 0.7 molar eq Cd(II) but showed two 113Cd resonances with chemical shifts of 581 and 589 ppm. Integration of the two signals showed a 1.0:0.6 ratio (Fig. 7B). The enrichment of one of the 113Cd signals suggests that a limited preference exists in one zinc finger motif for 113Cd binding. In an attempt to identify which finger motif showed the preferential Cd(II) binding, a ZF3/4 mutant peptide containing a C2Q2 site in ZF4 was purified, and 1 molar eq 113Cd(II) was added. Cd(II) was not retained in this peptide, consistent with the lack of Zn(II) binding in the mutant peptides. The absence of Cd(II) binding to the mutant ZF3/4 peptide suggests that the two signals observed in the Cd1·ZF3/4 peptide complex arises from limited cooperativity in Cd(II) binding. To address binding cooperativity in the ZF3/4 finger pair, the purified peptide was reconstituted with varying amounts of Zn(II), and the samples were subjected to electrospray mass spectrometry to identify noncovalent zinc·peptide complexes. Samples reconstituted with 0.4, 0.8, and 1.2 mol equiv Zn(II) showed the appearance of Zn1·ZF3/4 and Zn2·ZF3/4 complexes (Fig. 8). The abundance of the Zn2·ZF3/4 species was not significantly different from theoretical predictions of random binding events. Assuming the electrospray ionization process did not introduce artifactual distribution of species, the clear interpretation was that Zn(II) binding was largely noncooperative in the ZF3/4 finger pair peptide. The zinc finger pair domain is found in many eukaryotic genomes. The yeast genome contains three such finger pair domains. Two of these domains reside in Zap1, and the third domain is found in Rim101. The two finger pair domains in Zap1 each bind 2 molar eq Zn(II) and with similar binding affinities (8Bird A.J. McCall K. Kramer M. Blankman E. Winge D.R. Eide D.J. EMBO J. 2003; 22: 5137-5146Crossref PubMed Scopus (97) Google Scholar). However, the two finger pair domains exhibit differential Zn(II) binding properties. The finger pair domain containing the AD2 transactivation segment, ZF1/2, exhibits kinetic lability in Zn(II) binding, unlike the finger pair domain from the Zap1 DBD, ZF3/4, or Gli. The hallmark of this novel domain is the packing of two zinc finger motifs together into one globular unit. The domain is stabilized by a hydrophobic interface between the two motifs. As such, one prediction is that polypeptide folding and Zn(II) binding would occur in a cooperative manner. A second prediction is that Zn(II) binding to a single finger motif of a paired domain would be highly destabilized in the absence of Zn(II) binding to the second finger. We show here that Zn(II) bind weakly to the single finger motifs of the ZF3/4 finger pair domain. A peptide containing the ZF3/4 finger pair with a C2H2 → C2Q2 substitution in ZF4 failed to retain bound Zn(II) in ZF3 during buffer dialysis. Likewise, a peptide containing the ZF1/2 finger pair with a C2H2 → C2Q2 substitution in ZF2 failed to retain bound Zn(II) in ZF1 during buffer dialysis. Limited binding cooperativity was observed in Cd(II) but not Zn(II) binding. The dependence of having two finger motifs together to form a stable finger pair domain suggests that interactions between the two motifs contribute to the binding energy of the zinc-folded conformer. During the review process of this manuscript, a report appeared on the structure of the Zap1 ZF1/2 finger pair domain (17Wang Z. Feng L.S. Matskevich V. Venkataraman K. Parasuraam P. Laity J.H. J. Mol. Biol. 2006; 357: 1167-1183Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar). The domain consists of two interacting fingers stabilized by a highly cooperative hydrophobic interface. The observed instability of individual fingers is consistent with the results of our study. The division of zinc finger pair domains into two classes of Zn(II) binding lability motivated our efforts to map the determinant conferring lability in Zn(II) binding. Inspection of the sequences of the two peptides revealed little sequence conservation. Therefore, finger pair chimeras between ZF1/2 and ZF3/4 were engineered to map the lability determinants. Replacement of the labile ZF2 within ZF1/2 by the stable ZF4 motif, creating a ZF1/4 chimera, resulted in a domain that exhibited stable Zn(II) ion binding. Thus, one important new observation is that a stable zinc finger motif can impart stability to a labile motif, thereby reducing reactivity with Zn(II) chelators. A ZF3/2 chimera constructed by replacing ZF1 by ZF3 with the interfinger linker being from ZF2 showed an intermediate reactivity with PAR, EDTA, and 1,10-OP. The PAR reactivity predicted that, as with the ZF1/4 chimera, the presence of a stable finger motif in conjunction with a labile motif leads to diminished reactivity with chelators. However, the diminished PAR reactivity of the ZF3/2 chimera was not equivalent to the observed stability of the ZF3/4 or ZF1/4 finger pair domains. Zinc metalloregulation of AD activity of the ZF3/2 chimera in vivo was also intermediate. Whereas both ZF1/2 and ZF3/2 exhibited similar AD activity when tested with the Gal4 DBD in zinc-deficient cells, the inhibition of activity of the ZF3/2 chimera in zinc-replete cells was incomplete relative to ZF1/2. The inability to the ZF3/2 to be fully inhibited in zinc-replete cells may arise from compromised cooperativity of packing the two nonnative finger motifs together in a single globular domain. Defects in forming a stable globular domain would impart partial constitutive AD activity. The higher transcriptional activity of the ZF3/2 finger pair relative to the ZF1/2 pair under zinc-replete conditions suggests that ZF3/2 binds zinc less stably relative to ZF1/2. In contrast, the in vitro chelator competition data suggest that Zn(II) binding to the ZF3/2 pair is more stable than the ZF1/2 pair predicting a more zinc-repressed state. The apparent discrepancy may simply be due to subtle differences in the thermodynamics rather than kinetics of Zn(II) binding. In addition, the in vivo regulation may be more complex than merely Zn(II) binding kinetics. For example, a post-translational modification that is absent in the ZF3/2 finger pair may be required to maintain the ZF1/2 finger pair in a fully repressed state. It is noteworthy that a number of the GBD-AD2 fusion proteins fail to accumulate to high levels in vivo (Fig. 3C, constructs 3 and 4). The active form of a number of transcription factors is subject to ubiquitin-mediated proteolysis (18Muratani M. Kung C. Shokat K.M. Tansey W.P. Cell. 2005; 120: 887-899Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar). As a consequence, their stability decreases when they are active. Our current studies are investigating whether AD2 is modified post-translationally. Two lines of evidence links the kinetic lability in Zn(II) binding to the α-helix of ZF2. First, the ZF1/ZFβ2α4 chimera resembles ZF3/4 in Zn(II) binding stability in in vitro incubation studies with the 1/10-OP and EDTA chelators. This result predicts that the ZF1/ZFβ2α4 chimera would render the finger pair in the zinc-bound state in vivo. The GAL4 minimal Zap1 construct containing the ZF1/ZFβ2α4 chimera was attenuated in AD activity, yet we cannot be certain this arises from stable Zn(II) binding or loss of AD activity by removing the α2 helix in ZF2. Second, substitution of the α2 helix in ZF2 in place of the helix in ZF4 creating a ZF3/ZFβ4α2 chimera imparted in vitro Zn(II) binding lability (Fig. 5). Zinc regulation of AD activity of ZF2, therefore, appears dependent on the α-helix segment of ZF2 as well as determinants in ZF1. The linker in ZF1/ZF2 does not appear to be a component of Zn(II) binding lability. Replacement of ZF1 with ZF3 yields an inferior sensory domain, but AD activity is largely retained. Thus, AD activity is not totally dependent on ZF1 in the finger pair domain. The zinc sensory function of the ZF1/2 domain is novel. With the conservation of this domain seen in multiple eukaryotic genomes, one challenge is to determine whether other finger pair domains exist that are zinc sensory. Zinc finger pair domains found in animal genomes tend to be in one of three contexts. Finger pair domains are seen in putative DNA-binding domains in which the finger pair domain is adjacent to a series of classical zinc finger motifs as in Gli and Zap1. An alternative arrangement is the presence of a finger pair domain adjacent to one classical zinc finger. The third context is the presence of paired finger domains isolated from any classical zinc fingers. Proteins in any of these three categories may conceivably be sensory to the cellular zinc status. The identification of other zinc sensory domains in mammalian genomes may provide insight into other cellular functions that may be modulated by the cellular zinc status. The ideal scenario is to use computational approaches to identify candidates, but this obvious approach is complicated by the present lack of predictive features of zinc sensory finger pair domains. Future studies may help define the structural determinants conferring lability on zinc finger pairs. For example, purification of recombinant finger pair domain peptides and testing by chelator reactivity may provide the most revealing information. These studies are in progress. The angiotensin II type 1A receptor (AT<sub>1A</sub>R) plays an important role in cardiovascular function and as such represents a primary target for therapeutic intervention. The AT<sub>1A</sub>R is coupled via G<sub>q</sub> to the activation of phospholipase C, the hydrolysis of phosphoinositides, release of calcium from intracellular stores, and the activation of protein kinase C (PKC). We show here that PKCβI and PKCβII exhibit different membrane translocation patterns in response to AT<sub>1A</sub>R agonist activation. Whereas PKCβII translocation to the membrane is transient, PKCβI displays additional translocation responses: persistent membrane localization and oscillations between the membrane and cytosol following agonist removal. The initial translocation of PKCβI requires the release of calcium from intracellular stores and the activation of phospholipase C, but persistent membrane localization is dependent upon extracellular calcium influx. The mutation of any of the three PKC phosphorylation consensus sites (Ser-331, Ser-338, and Ser-348) localized within the AT<sub>1A</sub>R C-tail significantly increases the probability that persistent increases in diacylglycerol levels and PKCβI translocation responses will be observed. The persistent increase in AT<sub>1A</sub>R-mediated diacylglycerol formation is mediated by the activation of phospholipase D. Although the persistent PKCβI membrane translocation response is absolutely dependent upon the PKC activity-dependent recruitment of an extracellular calcium current, it does not require the activation of phospholipase D. Taken together, we show that the patterning of AT<sub>1A</sub>R second messenger response patterns is regulated by heterologous desensitization and PKC isoform substrate specificity.

The RNA-dependent RNA polymerase of the hepatitis C virus and the bovine viral diarrhea virus(BVDV)is able to initiate RNA synthesis denovo in the absence of a primer. Previous crystallographic data have pointed to the existence of a GTP-specific binding site (G-site) that is located in the vicinity of the active site of the BVDV enzyme. Here we have studied the functional role of the G-site and present evidence to show that specific GTP binding affects the positioning of the template during de novo initiation. Following the formation of the first phosphodiester bond, the polymerase translocates relative to the newly synthesized dinucleotide, which brings the 5'-end of the primer into the G-site, releasing the previously bound GTP. At this stage, the 3'-end of the template can remain opposite to the 5'-end of the primer or be repositioned to its original location before RNA synthesis proceeds. We show that the template can freely move between the two locations, and both complexes can isomerize to equilibrium. These data suggest that the bound GTP can stabilize the interaction between the 3'-end of the template and the priming nucleotide, preventing the template to overshoot and extend beyond the active site during de novo initiation. The hepatitis C virus enzyme utilizes a dinucleotide primer exclusively from the blunt end; the existence of a functionally equivalent G-site is therefore uncertain. For the BVDV polymerase we showed that de novo initiation is severely compromised by the T320A mutant that likely affects hydrogen bonding between the G-site and the guanine base. Dinucleotide-primed reactions are not influenced by this mutation, which supports the notion that the G-site is located in close proximity but not at the active site of the enzyme.

Ribonucleotide reductase class I enzymes consist of two non-identical subunits, R1 and R2, the latter containing a diiron carboxylate center and a stable tyrosyl radical (Tyr·), both essential for catalysis. Catalysis is known to involve highly conserved amino acid residues covering a range of ∼35Å and a concerted mechanism involving long range electron transfer, probably coupled to proton transfer. A number of residues involved in electron transfer in both the R1 and R2 proteins have been identified, but no direct model has been presented regarding the proton transfer side of the process. Arg265 is conserved in all known sequences of class Ia R2. In this study we have used site-directed mutagenesis to gain insight into the role of this residue, which lies close to the catalytically essential Asp266 and Trp103. Mutants to Arg265 included replacement by Ala, Glu, Gln, and Tyr. All mutants of Arg265 were found to have no or low catalytic activity with the exception of Arg265 to Glu, which shows ∼40% of the activity of native R2. We also found that the Arg mutants were capable of stable tyrosyl radical generation, with similar kinetics of radical formation and R1 binding as native R2. Our results, supported by molecular modeling, strongly suggest that Arg265 is involved in the proton-coupled electron transfer pathway and may act as a proton mediator during catalysis. At the protein level the activity is determined by 1) R1/R2 interactions, 2) formation and maintenance in protein R2 of a tyrosyl radical neighboring a diiron carboxylate site, which contains two high spin ferric ions antiferromagnetically coupled by one μ-oxo bridge and one μ-carboxylate bridge, and 3) positive and negative nucleotide allosteric effectors acting in protein R1. The overall enzyme activity is controlled by the limiting levels of protein R2 that are undetectable in the G1 phase and increase in the S phase (10Chang C.H. Cheng Y.C. Cancer Res. 1979; 39: 5081-5086PubMed Google Scholar, 11Rova U. Goodtzova K. Ingemarson R. Behravan G. Gräslund A. Thelander L. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 4267-4275Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar). In vitro, the tyrosyl radical is formed by loss of an electron and a proton in a reconstitution reaction between apoprotein R2, ferrous iron, and molecular oxygen. The R1 protein binds the substrate and allosteric effectors, whereas R2 contains the radical harboring tyrosyl residue, Tyr177, in mouse R2. During catalysis it is proposed that the oxidation equivalent stored in the tyrosyl side chain in R2 is transferred through an ∼35-Å-long pathway to a cysteine residue at the active site, Cys429, in the R1 protein (12Andersson K.K. Gräslund A. Adv. Inorg. Biochem. 1995; 43: 359-408Crossref Scopus (84) Google Scholar, 13Nordlund P. Sjöberg B.M. Eklund H. Nature. 1994; 370: 533-539Crossref PubMed Scopus (511) Google Scholar). The catalytically active cysteinyl radical on Cys429 is proposed to act directly on the substrate. The x-ray structures of proteins R1 and R2 are in agreement with a PCET mechanism mediated by hydrogen bonds connecting the residues (15Uhlin U. Eklund H. In the amino acid sequence of protein R2 the arginine residue, Arg265, is conserved in all R2 sequences known so far. In fact, it seems to be part of the fingerprint that characterizes R2 proteins. It has also been hypothesized that it participates in the PCET pathway based on the crystal structures of E. coli R2 and Salmonella typhimurium R2F proteins (3Eklund H. Uhlin U. Färnegårdh M. In fact, in all presently solved crystal structures of R2 protein from six different organisms the arginine residue is connected to the PCET pathway residues either by a direct hydrogen bond to the Asp266 or in most cases via a water molecule that is located between Asp266 and Trp103. The position of Arg265, the fact that it is highly conserved and that it has been found to be coordinated to a water molecule residing in the vicinity of Asp266 and Trp103, suggest that it may play a role in the PCET transfer process. Taking into consideration the biochemical characteristics of arginine, this residue could most likely be involved in the proton transfer part of the PCET pathway rather than in electron transfer part. It has also been suggested to be involved in R1 binding (3Eklund H. Uhlin U. Färnegårdh M. Logan D.T. Nordlund P. Prog. Biophys. Mol. An arginine residue has been identified as the proton donor in the reduction of fumarate. We have investigated the enzymatic activity in mouse RNR containing either native protein R2 or selected point mutants designed to probe the role of Arg265 as a proton mediator. Point mutations include replacement of Arg265 either by alanine, glutamate, glutamine, or tyrosine. In addition we have studied the formation of the tyrosyl radical in the reconstitution as well as the kinetics of radical formation in the mutants. Results indicate the Arg265 is crucial to catalysis but is not directly involved in tyrosyl radical formation. Expression and Purification of R2 Proteins—Site-directed mutagenesis was achieved using the QuikChange® II site-directed mutagenesis kit from Stratagene. The mouse proteins were overexpressed in logarithmically growing Rosetta 2(DE3)pLysS bacteria containing pETR2 plasmids encoding native mouse R2 protein or the mutant mouse R2 proteins Arg to Ala (R265A), Arg to Glu (R265E), Arg to Gln (R265Q), or Arg to Tyr (R265Y). For expression of native and R2 mutants, an overnight culture of Rosetta 2(DE3)pLysS inoculated with native or mutant R2 was diluted 200 times in 4.8 liters of Luria-Bertani medium containing 34 μg/ml chloramphenicol and 100 μg/ml carbenicillin. The bacteria were grown at 37 °C until they reached an A595 of 0.6 and then induced with 400 μm isopropyl-1-thio-β-d-galactopyranoside and grown for an additional 3 h before harvesting. The native and mutant proteins were purified as previously described in Mann et al. (41Mann G.J. Gräslund A. Ochiai E.I. Ingemarson R. Thelander L. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 1939-1947Crossref PubMed Scopus (144) Google Scholar) with a small modification. Grinding with aluminum oxide was omitted due to the presence of pLys in the vector. This preparation resulted in iron-containing R2 protein. To obtain R2 apoprotein, the same procedure was employed except that 0.2 mm EDTA was added 20 min before induction, and all purification buffers contained 0.2 mm EDTA. Preparation of the Anaerobic Fe2+ Solution—Buffer containing 50 mm Tris-HCl was thoroughly degassed in a septum-sealed 250-ml bulb for several hours by flushing oxygen-free argon and evacuation. A second bulb containing Mohr's salt crystals, (NH4)2Fe(SO4)2, was sealed and evacuated using the same procedure. A plastic syringe was made anaerobic by repeated washing with oxygen-free argon gas. Then the appropriate volume of degassed buffer was used to prepare the desired iron concentration by transferring the buffer into the bulb containing Mohr's salt. Reconstitution Reaction of Apoprotein R2 with Fe2+ and Oxygen—Reconstitution of the iron site in the R2 proteins were carried out by mixing oxygen saturated apoprotein R2 with anaerobic Fe2+ solution. Rapid freeze quench was performed with a System 1000 apparatus from Update Instruments to obtain reaction times from 20 ms to 1 s. The EPR tubes were submerged in isopentane at a temperature of –110 °C. Anaerobic iron solution and apoprotein were rapidly mixed and then quenched by spraying them onto the EPR tube. The crystals were tightly packed into the tube using a packing rod made from Teflon. Isopentane from the EPR tube was completely removed by placing the tubes under vacuum for 15 min. For reaction times above 1 s, slow-freeze quench was achieved by hand mixing. A gas-tight Hamilton syringe washed several times with anaerobic Fe2+ was used to reconstitute the aerobic apoprotein previously placed in an EPR tube. Reactions were quenched by immersion of the EPR tubes into cold isopentane at –110 °C. To assess the reconstitution efficiency after EPR measurements, the protein was passed through a NAP™ 5 column to remove excess iron. The total iron content was determined using an iron/TIBC (ferrozine) reagent set from Eagle Diagnostics. Ribonucleotide Reductase Activity Assay—The ability of native and mutant R2 proteins to catalyze the reduction of [3H]CDP in the presence of R1 protein was determined as described earlier (42Engström Y. Eriksson S. Thelander L. Åkerman M. Biochemistry. 1979; 18: 2941-2948Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar). One unit is defined as the amount of protein that, in excess of R1 protein, catalyzes the formation of 1 nmol of dCDP/min at 37 °C. The following reagents were incubated for 20 min at 37 °C in a total volume of 50 μl: 0.5 mm [3H]CDP, 3 mm ATP, 10 mm dithiothreitol (DTT), 100 mm KCl, 6.4 mm MgCl2, 0.02 mm FeCl3, and 40 mm HEPES buffer, pH 7.5. Surface Plasmon Resonance Analysis of R1-R2 Complex Formation—All surface plasmon resonance measurements were performed using Biacore 3000 equipped with research grade CM5 sensor chips. The R2 proteins were immobilized using the amino-coupling chemistry method as described earlier (11Rova U. Goodtzova K. Ingemarson R. Behravan G. Gräslund A. Thelander L. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 4267-4275Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar). After activation of the dextran layer, 30 ml of R2 proteins at concentrations of 40 μm were injected at a flow rate of 5 μl/min. The R2 proteins were allowed to interact with R1 protein at different concentrations previously equilibrated with HBS-EP buffer (10 mm HEPES, pH 7.4, 0.15 m NaCl, 3 mm EDTA, 0.005% surfactant P20) plus 2 mm DTT. Five different R1 concentrations were used to determine kinetics for the R1-R2 interactions. Increasing concentrations of pure R1 in the HBS-EP buffer containing 2 mm DTT and 0.125 mm dTTP were used to obtain kinetic data. A constant flow of 5 μl/min of the same running buffer was used as eluent during the subunit interaction. The surface was regenerated between each protein R1 with 10 μl of 0.5 m KCl in HBS-EP buffer. Data were collected and analyzed using the Bioeval 3.2 program to obtain relative unit values of bound R1 protein for each injection. Electron Paramagnetic Resonance Spectroscopy—X-band EPR spectra were measured on a Bruker ESP 300 spectrometer as described earlier (43Rova U. Adrait A. Pötsch S. Gräslund A. Thelander L. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 23746-23751Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). All spectra were recorded at 20 K. Biol. 1971; 55: 379-400Crossref PubMed Scopus (5345) Google Scholar). Insight II was also used to measure distances and minimize the structures containing the different amino acid replacements. The amino acids chosen to replace Arg265 were chosen either to be small and hydrophobic (Ala), negatively charged (Glu), polar and non-hydrogen bonding (Gln), or aromatic (Tyr). Formation of the Stable Tyrosyl Radical in Native and Mutant R2 Proteins—The tyrosyl radical is formed in vitro in a reaction between apoprotein R2, ferrous iron, and molecular oxygen. The formation of a tyrosyl radical was studied by EPR spectroscopy. The extent of tyrosyl formation was determined for the mutants. As can be seen in Fig. 2, R265E and R265Q mutants were both capable of forming stable Tyr· in similar amounts (difference of 10%) as the native R2 protein after reactivation with iron and oxygen. A similar result was found for the R265A and R265Y proteins (data not shown). The tyrosyl radical EPR spectra did not show any qualitative differences between the mutants and the native R2.
